title: 1787-A
statement: A. Exponential Equationtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given an integer $$$n$$$.Find any pair of integers $$$(x,y)$$$ ($$$1\\leq x,y\\leq n$$$) such that $$$x^y\\cdot y+y^x\\cdot x = n$$$.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1\\leq t\\leq 10^4$$$) â€” the number of test cases.Each test case contains one line with a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1\\leq n\\leq 10^9$$$).OutputFor each test case, if possible, print two integers $$$x$$$ and $$$y$$$ ($$$1\\leq x,y\\leq n$$$). If there are multiple answers, print any.Otherwise, print $$$-1$$$.ExampleInput537423125020732790Output-1 -1 2 3 5 5 3 13NoteIn the third test case, $$$2^3 \\cdot 3+3^2 \\cdot 2 = 42$$$, so $$$(2,3),(3,2)$$$ will be considered as legal solutions.In the fourth test case, $$$5^5 \\cdot 5+5^5 \\cdot 5 = 31250$$$, so $$$(5,5)$$$ is a legal solution.

processed.result:
You are given an integer $n$. Find two integers $x$ and $y$ (where $1 \le x, y \le n$) that satisfy the following equation:

$x^y \cdot y + y^x \cdot x = n$

If no such pair of integers exists, print $-1$.

Given a number, find two numbers less than or equal to it that, when used in the equation  (first number to the power of the second number) times the second number plus (second number to the power of the first number) times the first number, equal the given number. If no such pair exists, print -1.
